fields:
-During the CVS exam how would you position and expose the patient?
{{c1::Position patient at 45 degrees, exposed to the waist}}

General Inspection:

What might you be looking for in terms of patients breathing?
{{c1::Use of accessory muscles while breathing or dyspnoea}}

What might you be looking for at the patients bedside?
{{c1::GTN spray, ECG leads, telemetery box, oxygen, nasal prongs, mask , intubation etc.}}

What CVS condition is pallor associated with? {{c1::Anaemia}}
What CVS condition is cachexia associated with? {{c1::Congestive cardiac failure}}

What three chronic lifelong syndromes can be identified during the general cvs inspection and what are the signs of each
{{c1::-Marfans Syndrome (Tall, long arm span, high arched palate)
-Downs Syndrome (flattened appearance to face, low set small ears, short neck, protruding tongue)
-Turners Syndrome (Webbed neck)}}

CVS examination of the hands:


What is this?{{c1::xanthoma}}
What condition is it a sign of?{{c1::Hyperlipidemia}}
Where else on the body might you find it {{c1::Achilles tendon}}

What is the difference between Janeway Lesions and Osler Nodes?
{{c1::Osler nodes are raised and tender, while Janeway lesions are more erythymous and are not tender}}

What condition are they both a sign of? {{c1::Infective endocarditis}}

Finger clubbing is a sign of  {{c1::cyanotic congenital heart disease}} and {{c1::infective endocarditis}}

What is the other sign you would look for in CVS examination of the hands.
{{c1::Splinter hemorrhages}}

What is it a sign of ? 
{{c1::infective endocarditis, trauma, vasculitis}}

Pulse Examination

How do you take someone's pulse?
{{c1::Find Radial artery WITH THREE FINGERS}}

What constitutes Bradycardia? {{c1::<60}}bpm
What constitutes Tachycardia? {{c1::>100}}bpm

What is a radiofemoral delay indicative of? {{c1::coarctation of the aorta}}

What is a pulse deficit? {{c1::difference between apical and radial rates}}

What it is it indicative of?{{c1::Atrial fibliration}}

In a patient with pulse deficit you must auscultate instead of taking radial pulse.

Carotid Pulse

{{c1::volume }} is assessed at carotid pulse (hint: low value when dehydrated)

Character:
-{{c1::sinus arrhythmia}}-cyclical variation in pulse rate with respiration

-{{c1::collapsing pulse}}-  disappears momentarily on lifting arm- indicative of {{c1::aortic regurgitation}}

-{{c1::slow rising pulse}}- delayed up-stroke - indicative of {{c1::aortic stenosis}}

-{{c1::Pulsus ALternans}}-pulse with alternating strong and weak beats- indicative of {{c1::left ventricular failure}}

-{{c1::Jerky pulse}}- pulse with a double beat- idicative of {{c1::Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy}}

What is a carotid bruit?
{{c1::a vascular sound usually heard with a stethoscope over the carotid artery}}

What is it indicative of?
{{c1::stenosis – atherosclerotic disease}}

Blood Pressure

Normal-{{c1::•Normal <130/85}}
At what rate do you deflate the thingy? {{c1::•2-4 }}mmHg/s
What do you do if there's a difference of <10 mmHg between arms pressure? {{c1::Record the higher reading}} 

What contitutes postural hypotension? {{c1:– fall in systolic BP of >20mmHG on standing}}

Face Examination

What is it, what CVS condition could it be indicative of.


{{c1::Corneal arcus, high bp, high cholestrol}}

{{c1::Xanthelasmata, high bp high cholestrol }}

{{c1::•High arched palate (Marfan’s syndrome)}}

{{c1::•Malar flush (mitral stenosis)}}

{{c1::•Cyanosis, cyanotic heart disease}}


Palor indicates {{c1::anaemia}}
Dental caries is a risk factor for {{c1::infective endocarditis}}
Jaundice can mean there is {{c1::haemolysis from a synthetic heart valve}}

Jugular Venous Pressure, reflects {{c1::right atrial pressure}}

How would you set a patient up to check JVP?
{{c1::•Patient at 45 degrees
•Good lighting
Make sure you can see IJV}}

What are you looking for?

1.{{c1::height in cm that top of IJV is above sternal angle}} 
2.{{c1::A,C and V waves}}

JVP VISIBLE BUT NOT PALPABLE

Name 3 conditions that are indicated if JVP is above 3cm (3/5)
{{c1::•RV failure (nb)
•Tricuspid regurgitation
•Pericardial effusion
•SVC obstruction
Fluid overload (nb}}

A-wave is {{c1::Right atrium contracting}}
C-wave is {{c1::Right ventricle contracting}}
V-wave is {{c1::Emptying finished ventricles relax}}

Praecordium:{{c1:: the portion of the body over the heart and lower chest}}

On the praecordium there may be scars 
Match the condition/ procedure to the type of scar

Median sternotomy, lateral thoracotomy, infraclavicular

Coronary artery bypass graft {{c1::ms}}
Pacemaker insertion {{c1::ic}}
lobectomy {{c1::lt}}
Complications from TB {{c1::lt}}
Valve replacement {{c1::ms}}
pneumonectomy {{c1::LT}}

What is pectus excavatum? {{c1::the breastbone sunken into chest}}

Where is the normal location for the apex beat?
{{c1::5th Intercostal space in midclavicular line (generally you'll find it by placing three fingers of right hand on chest till you find lowermost palpable beat)}}

Character of Apex Beat

A heaving (very strong) beat can be indicative of conditions like fluid overload or cardiac hypertrophy but what is a left parasternal heave in particular indicative of? {{c1::Right ventricular hypertrophy – e.g. secondary to lung disease}}

What are thrills? {{c1::murmurs that are palpable}}
Systolic thrill can mean {{c1::aortic stenosis, mitral regurg}}
Diastolic thrill can mean {{c1::mitral stenosis}}

Palpate for Pacemaker box or defibrillator

Praecordium: Auscultation of heart sounds  

•Bell – {{c1::low}} pitched sounds – careful not to put pressure on the bell
•Diaphragm – {{c1::high}} pitched sounds
•Begin with bell at {{c1::Mitral}} - {{c1::Tricuspid}} - {{c1::Pulmonary}} - {{c1::Aortic}} areas
•Then diaphragm at {{c1::Mitral}} - {{c1::Tricuspid}} - {{c1::Pulmonary}} - {{c1::Aortic}}  areas

Where is every place
•Mitral: {{c1::midclavicular line, 5th intercostal space}}
•Tricuspid: {{c1::left of sternal boarder, 5th intercostal space}}
•Pulmonary: {{c1::left of sternal boarder, 2nd intercostal space}}
•Aortic: {{c1::right of sternal boarder, 2nd intercostal space}}

Heart Sounds

1st heart sounds- 
Made by {{c1::mitral}} and {{c1::tricuspid}} valve closure

What part of stethescope do you hear it with? {{c1::bell and diaphragm}}

Where is it heard loudest? {{c1::apex}}

Loud heart sound can indicate
-{{c1::tachy}}cardia
-{{c1::mitral stenosis}}
-Left atrial myxoma, what is a myxoma? {{c1::benign (non-cancerous) growth in the heart}}

Soft heart sound can indicate
-Mitral {{c1::regurgitation}}
-{{c1::Myocardial infarction}}
-{{c1::Left}} bundle branch block
-{{c1::First degree}} heart block

2nd Heart Sound

Made by {{c1::Aortic}} and {{c1::Pulmonary}} valve closure

What is splitting of the second heart sound?
{{c1::The aortic valve closes slightly before the pulmonary valve so there is a technically two sounds in the second heart sound, A2, P2}}

Where can you hear the splitting most well?
{{c1::•During inspiration at left of sternal boarder, 2nd intercostal space}}

What does a wide physiologic splitting mean? and what does it indicate?
{{c1::occurs during inspiration, A2P2 interval widens further}}
{{c1::Right bundle branch block }}

What does a wide fixed splitting mean? and what does it indicate?
{{c1::occurs during inspiration and expiration, A2P2 remains very wide}}
{{c1::atrial septal defect, right heart failure}}

What does reversed splitting mean? and what does it indicate?
{{c1::A2 follows P2}}
{{c1::Left bundle branch block, aortic stenosis}}

Third Heart Sound

•{{c1::Low}} pitched (best heard with the {{c1::Bell}}) sound occurring in mid-diastole

{{c1::Gallop}} rhythm

Lub  dubub/kentucky

Originates in ventricle from {{c1::rapid ventricular filling}}

May be normal in <{{c1::35yrs }}

Indicative of 
1.{{c1::congestive cardiac failure}}
2.Mitral {{c1::regurgitation}}
3.Ventricular septal defect
4.Atrial septal defect (right ventricular S3)
5.Aortic {{c1::regurgitation}}

Fourth Heart Sound

•Late diastole
•Immediately before S1
•Due to a {{c1::Stiff ventricle}}
•Abnormal at any age
•be lub  dup  be lub   dup
•Cadence similar to “Tennessee…Tennessee”

Indicative of 
1.{{c1::Hyper}}tension
2.Ischaemic {{c1::cardiomyopathy}}
3.{{c1::Hypertrophic}} cardiomyopathy (HCM)
4.{{c1::Aortic}} stenosis

Miscellanous heart sound stuff
•Can be difficult to distinguish S1 and S2: feel carotid pulse during auscultation:
  Carotid impulse occurs just after S1
  S2 occurs after the impulse

Prosthetic heart valve sounds
•Mechanical valves (vs biological)
•Clicking / metallic quality
•Crisp sound

Murmurs 

What are the 5 characteristics of a murmur
{{c1::timing, site of maximal intensity, loudness, radiation, dynamic movements}}

Timing of Murmurs

Systolic
Match the systolic murmur type to the conditions it indicates
Pansystolic, Ejection Systolic, Late Systolic


Aortic stenosis{{c1::ES}}
Pulmonary stenosis{{c1::ES}}
Tricuspid regurgitation{{c1::PS}}
Mitral valve prolapse{{c1::LS}}
Mitral regurgitation{{c1::PS}}
Ventricular septal defect{{c1::PS}}
HOCM {{c1::ES}}
Atrial septal defect{{c1::ES}}

Which is loudest in midsystole or later? {{c1::Ejection systolic
•Crescendo-decrescendo}}

Diastolic

What conditions are associated with early diastolic murmur?
{{c1::•Aortic regurgitation
•Pulmonary regurgitation}}

What condition is associated with a mid diastolic murmur?
{{c1::mitral stenosis}}

Continuous

What conditions are associated with a continuous murmur

{{c1::•Patent ductus arteriosus
•Arteriovenous fistula}}

What is a pericardial friction rub
{{c1::grating, to-and-fro sound produced by friction of the heart against the pericardium}}

What does Site of maximal intensity of a murmur mean ?
{{c1::•The place on the precordium where the murmur is heard most easily}}

•Loudness is not always representative of the severity of a valve lesion (e.g. in severe valve stenosis murmur may be soft).

Dynamic Moanoeuvres-

What murmurs become louder on inspiration?{{c1::Right sided murmurs}}

What murmurs become louder on expiration?{{c1::Left sided murmurs}}

What would you be looking for if you get the patient to lean forward and breath all the way out?{{c1::aortic regurgitation}}

What would you be looking for if you got patient s to roll to left side?{{c1::Mitral Stenosis}}

What do you get patient to do in valsalva?{{c1::•Ask patient to pinch nose with fingers, close mouth and breath out hard so as to pop eardrums.
•Listen over left sternal edge}}

note_models.name: Cloze
